references: To ensure the general applicability of our primary analysis in the main manuscript (Sec. 4.1), we perform additional experiments within the same setup, using different training datasets. Here, we replace the training domain from VisDrone with Okutama-Action or ICG (Tab. 3). Consistent with our primary analysis, using the pose-diversified synthetic dataset generally results in higher accuracy than using the original synthetic dataset, with one exception: when leveraging synthetic data for training using PTL and testing trained detectors on the ICG test set.

Numbers in the parentheses represent accuracy gain/loss of the pose-diversified synthetic dataset compared to the original synthetic dataset.

references: In Table 1, we compare the detection accuracy when using the original synthetic dataset (‘real + orig’), the pose-diversified synthetic dataset (‘real + p-div’), and neither (‘real’) for training. In all cases except for one (Vis-50 tested on the Okutama-Action dataset), leveraging synthetic data for training provides better accuracy than using only real training images. Even in this one exceptional case, using the pose-diversified synthetic dataset results in higher accuracy. This result demonstrates the impact of using synthetic data in training on improving detection performance.

S4.T2.caption: Table 2: Pose-diversified synthetic dataset ablation experiments. The reported detection accuracies (‘acc’) are based on the same-domain Vis-20 setup.(a) # final target poses is closely related to the data size. Performance is insensitive to the data size.(b) post-processing. Noisy image filtering (‘filt.’) enhances the image quality and occlusion insertion (‘occ.’) improves the detection accuracy.
S4.T2.table:
acc.↑↑\uparrow
# tp # img FID↓↓\downarrow PT-FT PTL
  3 10,620 114.90 1.25/ 3.90 2.38/7.78
5 17,714 116.41  1.21/ 4.02 2.26/7.39
7 24,912 117.91  1.19/4.25 2.22/7.17
post-proc. acc.↑↑\uparrow
filt. occ. # img FID↓↓\downarrow PT-FT PTL
  ✗ ✗ 34,403 124.53  0.89/ 2.83  1.90/ 6.14
✓ ✗ 17,714 116.17  0.94/ 3.03  0.12/ 6.46
✗ ✓ 34,403 121.71  1.11/ 3.98  1.95/ 6.61
✓ ✓ 17,714 116.41 1.21/4.02 2.26/7.39
references: Number of final target poses for each synthetic image. Table 2(a) investigates the effects of using different number of final target poses for each original synthetic image. In this study, we scale the parameter up to 7 (i.e., 3, 5, and 7), proportionally increasing the number of total generated images. Image quality and detection accuracy do not change significantly even when the data size, controlled by changing the number of final target poses, varies. Therefore, we use 5 final target poses as default, which generates a number of images comparable to the size of the original synthetic dataset.

Post-processing. We study the effect of post-processing in Table 2(b). Filtering noisy images generally results in lower FID. The results demonstrate that noisy images are properly filtered, improving the image quality of the pose-diversified synthetic data. Moreover, it is observed that improving the image quality through this filtering process also increases the detection accuracy. On the other hand, taking occlusions into account does not improve the image quality in terms of FID, but it is useful in increasing the detection accuracy.
